I said, “Oh, if only I had wings like a dove!
Then would I fly away and be at rest.
v 7
See, then I would wander far away;
I would stay in the wilderness.
Selah
v 8
I would hurry to a shelter
from the stormy wind and tempest.”
v 9
Devour them, Lord, confuse their language!
For I have seen violence and strife in the city.
Day and night they go about on its walls;
wickedness and trouble are in the middle of it.
Wickedness is in the middle of it;
oppression and deceit do not leave its streets.
For it was not an enemy who rebuked me,
then I could have borne it;
neither was it he who hated me who raised himself up against me,
then I would have hidden myself from him.
But it was you, a man equal to myself,
my companion and my close friend.
We had sweet fellowship together;
we walked in the house of God with the throng.
Let death come suddenly on them;
let them go down alive to Sheol,
for wickedness is where they live, right among them.
As for me, I will call on God,
and Yahweh will save me.
In the evening, morning and at noonday I complain and moan;
he will hear my voice.
He will safely rescue my life from the battle that was against me,
for those who fought against me were many.
God, the one who rules from eternity,
will hear them and humiliate them.
Selah
They never change,
and they do not fear God.
My friend has raised his hands against those who were at peace with him;
he has not respected the covenant that he had.
His mouth was smooth as butter,
but his heart was hostile;
his words were softer than oil,
yet they were actually drawn swords.
Place your burdens on Yahweh, and he will sustain you;
he will never allow a righteous person to totter.
But you, God, will bring the wicked down into the pit of destruction;
bloodthirsty and deceitful men will not live even half as long as others,
but I will trust in you.
For the chief musician; set to Jonath elem rehokim. A psalm of David. A michtam; when the Philistines took him in Gath.
v 1
Be merciful to me, God, for men are attacking me!
All the day long those who fight me press their assault.
v 2
My enemies trample me all day long;
for there are many who arrogantly fight against me.
v 3
When I am afraid,
I will put my trust in you.
v 4
In God, whose word I praise—
in God I have put my trust; I will not be afraid;
what can mere man do to me?
v 5
All the day long they twist my words;
all their thoughts are against me for evil.
v 6
They gather themselves together, they hide themselves,
and they mark my steps,
just as they have waited for my life.
v 7
Do not let them escape doing iniquity.
Bring down the peoples in your anger, God.
v 8
You number my wanderings
and put my tears into your bottle;
are they not in your book?
v 9
Then my enemies will turn back on the day that I call to you;
this I know, that God is for me.
In God—whose word I praise,
in Yahweh—whose word I praise,
in God I trust,
I will not be afraid.
What can anyone do to me?
The duty to fulfill my vows to you is on me, God;
I will give thank offerings to you.
For you have rescued my life from death;
you have kept my feet from falling,
so that I may walk before God
in the light of the living.
For the chief musician; set to Al Tashheth. A psalm of David. A michtam; when he fled from Saul, in the cave.
v 1
Be merciful to me, God, be merciful to me,
for I take refuge in you until these troubles are over.
I stay under your wings for protection until this destruction is over.
v 2
I will cry to God Most High,
to God, who does all things for me.
v 3
He will send help from heaven and save me,
he is angry with those who crush me.
Selah
God will send me his loving kindness and his faithfulness.
v 4
My life is among lions;
I am among those who are ready to devour me.
I am among people whose teeth are spears and arrows,
and whose tongues are sharp swords.
v 5
Be exalted, God, above the heavens;
let your glory be above all the earth.
v 6
They spread out a net for my feet;
I was distressed.
They dug a pit in front of me.
They themselves have fallen into the middle of it!
Selah
v 7
My heart is fixed, God, my heart is fixed;
I will sing, yes, I will sing praises.
v 8
Wake up, my honored heart; wake up, lute and harp;
I will wake up the dawn.
v 9
I will give thanks to you, Lord, among the peoples;
I will sing praises to you among the nations.
For great is your unfailing love, reaching to the heavens;
and your faithfulness to the clouds.
Be exalted, God, above the heavens;
may your glory be exalted over all the earth.
For the chief musician; set to Al Tashheth. A psalm of David. A michtam.
v 1
Do you rulers speak righteousness?
Do you judge uprightly, you people?
v 2
No, you commit wickedness in your heart;
you distribute violence throughout the land with your hands.
v 3
The wicked go astray even when they are in the womb;
they go astray from birth, speaking lies.
v 4
Their poison is like a snake’s poison;
they are like a deaf adder that stops up its ears,
v 5
that pays no attention to the voice of charmers,
no matter how skillful they are.
v 6
Break their teeth in their mouths, God;
break out the great teeth of the young lions, Yahweh.
v 7
Let them melt away as water that runs off;
when they shoot their arrows, let them be as though they had no points.
v 8
Let them be like a snail that melts and passes away,
like the untimely-born child of a woman that never sees the sunlight.
v 9
Before your pots can feel the thorn’s burning heat,
he will take them away with a whirlwind, the green thorns and the burning thorns alike.
The righteous will rejoice when he sees God’s vengeance;
he will wash his feet in the blood of the wicked,
so that men will say, “Truly, there is a reward for the righteous person;
truly there is a God who judges the earth.”
For the chief musician; set to Al Tashheth. A psalm of David. A michtam; when Saul sent, and they watched the house to kill him.
v 1
Rescue me from my enemies, my God;
set me on high away from those who rise up against me.
v 2
Keep me safe from the workers of iniquity,
and save me from the bloodthirsty men.
v 3
For, see, they wait in ambush to take my life.
The powerful men gather themselves together against me,
but not because of my transgression or my sin, Yahweh.
v 4
They prepare to run at me although I am without fault;
awake and help me and see.
v 5
You, Yahweh God of hosts, the God of Israel,
arise and punish all the nations;
do not be merciful to any wicked transgressors.
Selah
v 6
They return at evening, they howl like dogs
and go around the city.
v 7
See, they belch out with their mouths;
swords are in their lips,
for they say, “Who hears us?”
v 8
But you, Yahweh, laugh at them;
you hold all the nations in derision.
v 9
God, my strength, I will pay attention to you;
you are my high tower.
My God will meet me with his covenant faithfulness;
God will let me see my desire on my enemies.
Do not kill them, or my people will forget.
Scatter them by your power and make them fall, Lord our shield.
For the sins of their mouths and the words of their lips,
let them be captured in their pride,
and for the curses and lies that they express.
Consume them in wrath, consume them so that they will be no more;
let them know that God rules in Jacob
and to the ends of the earth.
Selah
At evening they return,
howling like dogs going around the city.
They wander about looking for food
and they growl like a dog if they are not satisfied.
But I will sing about your strength,
and in the morning I will sing about your steadfast love!
For you have been my high tower
and a refuge in the day of my distress.
To you, my strength, I will sing praises;
for God is my high tower, the God of covenant faithfulness.

For the chief musician; set to Shushan Eduth. A michtam of David, for teaching. When he fought with Aram Naharaim and with Aram Zobah, and Joab returned and killed twelve thousand Edomites in the Valley of Salt.
v 1
God, you have cast us off; you have broken through our defenses;
you have been angry; restore us again.
v 2
You have made the land tremble; you have torn it apart;
heal its fissures, for it is shaking.
v 3
You have made your people see difficult things;
you have made us drink the wine of staggering.
v 4
For those who honor you,
you have set up a banner
to be displayed against those who carry the bow.
Selah
v 5
So that those you love may be rescued,
rescue us with your right hand and answer me.
v 6
God has spoken in his holiness, “I will rejoice;
I will divide Shechem and apportion out the Valley of Succoth.
v 7
Gilead is mine, and Manasseh is mine;
Ephraim also is my helmet;
Judah is my scepter.
v 8
Moab is my washbasin;
over Edom I will throw my shoe;
I will shout in triumph because of Philistia.”
v 9
Who will bring me into the strong city?
Who will lead me to Edom?
But you, God, have you not rejected us?
You do not go into battle with our army.
Give us help against the enemy,
for man’s help is futile.
We will triumph with God’s help;
he will trample down our enemies.
For the chief musician; on a stringed instrument. A psalm of David.
v 1
Hear my cry, God;
attend to my prayer.
v 2
From the ends of the earth will I call to you when my heart is faint;
lead me to the rock that is higher than I.
v 3
For you have been a refuge for me,
a strong tower from the enemy.
v 4
Let me live in your tabernacle forever!
Let me take refuge under the shelter of your wings.
Selah
v 5
For you, God, have heard my vows,
you have given me the inheritance of those who honor your name.
v 6
You will prolong the king’s life;
his years will be like many generations.
v 7
He will remain before God forever.
v 8
I will sing praise to your name forever
so that I may perform my vows every day.
For the chief musician; after the manner of Jeduthun. A psalm of David.
v 1
I wait in silence for God alone;
my salvation comes from him.
v 2
He alone is my rock and my salvation;
he is my high tower; I will not be greatly moved.
v 3
How long, all of you, will you attack a man,
that you may tip him over
like a leaning wall or a shaky fence?
v 4
They consult with him only to bring him down from his honorable position;
they love to tell lies;
they bless him with their mouths, but in their hearts they curse him.
Selah
v 5
I wait in silence for God alone;
for my hope is set on him.
v 6
He alone is my rock and my salvation;
he is my high tower; I will not be moved.
v 7
With God is my salvation and my glory;
the rock of my strength and my refuge are in God.
v 8
Trust in him at all times, you people;
pour out your heart before him;
God is a refuge for us.
Selah
v 9
Surely men of low standing are vanity, and men of high standing are a lie;
they will weigh lightly in the scales;
weighed together, they are lighter than nothing.
Do not trust in oppression or robbery;
and do not hope uselessly in riches,
for they will bear no fruit; do not fix your heart on them.
God has spoken once,
twice have I heard this:
power belongs to God.
Also to you, Lord, belongs covenant faithfulness,
for you pay back every person for what he has done.
A psalm of David, when he was in the wilderness of Judah.
v 1
God, you are my God! I earnestly search for you,
my soul thirsts for you, and my flesh longs for you,
in a dry and weary land where there is no water.
v 2
So I have looked on you in the sanctuary,
to see your power and your glory.
v 3
Because your covenant faithfulness is better than life,
my lips will praise you.
v 4
So I will bless you while I live;
I will lift up my hands in your name.
v 5
It will be as if I ate a meal of marrow and fatness;
with joyful lips my mouth will praise you,
v 6
when I think about you on my bed
and meditate on you in the night hours.
v 7
For you have been my help,
and in the shadow of your wings I rejoice.
v 8
I cling to you;
your right hand supports me.
v 9
But those who seek to destroy my life
will go down into the lowest parts of the earth;
they will be given over to those whose hands use the sword,
and they will become food for the jackals.
But the king will rejoice in God;
everyone who swears by him will be proud of him,
but the mouth of those who speak lies will be stopped up.
For the chief musician. A psalm of David.
v 1
Hear my voice, God, listen to my complaint;
preserve my life from fear of my enemies.
v 2
Hide me from the secret plotting of evildoers,
from the commotion of the doers of iniquity.
v 3
They have sharpened their tongues like swords;
they have aimed their arrows, bitter words,
v 4
so that they may shoot from secret places at someone who is innocent;
suddenly they shoot at him and fear nothing.
v 5
They encourage themselves in an evil plan;
they consult privately together in order to set traps;
they say, “Who will see us?”
v 6
They invent sinful plans;
“We have finished,” they say, “a careful plan.”
The inner thoughts and hearts of man are deep.
v 7
But God will shoot them;
suddenly they will be wounded with his arrows.
v 8
They will be made to stumble, since their own tongues are against them;
all who see them will wag their heads.
v 9
All people will fear
and will declare God’s deeds.
They will wisely think about what he has done.
The righteous will be glad about Yahweh and will take refuge in him;
all the upright in heart will take pride in him.
For the chief musician. A psalm. A song of David.
v 1
For you, God in Zion, our praise waits;
our vows will be carried out to you.
v 2
You who hear prayer,
to you all flesh will come.
v 3
Iniquities prevail against us;
as for our transgressions, you will forgive them.
v 4
Blessed is the man whom you choose to bring near to you
so that he may live in your courts.
We will be satisfied with the goodness of your house,
your holy temple.
v 5
In righteousness you will answer us by doing amazing things,
God of our salvation;
you who are hope of all the ends of the earth
and of those who are far across the sea.
v 6
For it is you who made the mountains firm,
you who are belted with strength.
v 7
It is you who quiet the roaring of the seas,
the roaring of their waves,
and the commotion of the peoples.
v 8
Those who live in the uttermost parts of the earth are afraid of the evidence of your deeds;
you make the east and the west rejoice.
v 9
You come to help the earth; you water it;
you greatly enrich it;
the river of God is full of water;
you provide mankind grain when you have prepared the earth.
You water its furrows abundantly;
you settle down the furrows’ ridges;
you make them soft with rain showers;
you bless the sprouts between them.
You crown the year with your goodness,
and your wagon tracks overflow with abundance.
The pastures in the wilderness drip with dew,
and the hills are clothed with joy.
The pastures are clothed with flocks;
the valleys also are covered over with grain;
they shout for joy, and they sing.
For the chief musician. A song, a psalm.
v 1
Make a joyful noise to God, all the earth;
v 2
Sing out the glory of his name;
make his praise glorious.
v 3
Say to God, “How terrifying are your deeds!
By the greatness of your power your enemies will submit to you.
v 4
All the earth will worship you
and will sing to you;
they will sing to your name.”
Selah
v 5
Come and see the works of God;
he is fearsome in his deeds toward the sons of mankind.
v 6
He turned the sea into dry land;
they went through the river on foot;
there we rejoiced in him.
v 7
He rules forever by his might;
his eyes observe the nations;
let not the rebellious exalt themselves.
Selah
v 8
Give blessing to God, you people,
let the sound of his praise be heard.
v 9
He keeps us among the living,
and he does not permit our feet to slip.
For you, God, have tested us;
you have tested us as silver is tested.
You brought us into a net;
you laid a heavy burden on our backs.
You made people ride over our heads;
we went through fire and water,
but you brought us out into a spacious place.
I will come into your house with burnt offerings;
I will pay you my vows
which my lips promised
and my mouth spoke when I was in distress.
I will offer to you burnt offerings of fat animals
with the sweet aroma of rams;
I will offer bulls and goats.
Selah
Come and listen, all you who fear God,
and I will declare what he has done for my soul.
I cried to him with my mouth,
and he was praised with my tongue.
If I had seen sin within my heart,
the Lord would not have listened to me.
But God has truly heard;
he has paid attention to the voice of my prayer.
Blessed be God,
who has not turned away my prayer
or his covenant faithfulness from me.
For the chief musician; on stringed instruments. A psalm, a song.
v 1
May God be merciful to us and bless us
and cause his face to shine on us
Selah
v 2
so that your ways may be known on earth,
your salvation among all nations.
v 3
Let the peoples praise you, God;
let all the peoples praise you.
v 4
Oh, let the nations be glad and sing for joy,
for you will judge the peoples with justice
and govern the nations on earth.
Selah
v 5
Let the peoples praise you, God;
let all the peoples praise you.
v 6
The earth has yielded its harvest
and God, our God, has blessed us.
v 7
God has blessed us,
and all the ends of the earth honor him.
For the chief musician; A psalm of David, a song.
v 1
Let God arise; let his enemies be scattered;
let those also who hate him flee before him.
v 2
As smoke is driven away, so drive them away;
as wax melts before the fire,
so let the wicked perish in the presence of God.
v 3
But let the righteous be glad; let them exult before God;
may they rejoice and be happy.
v 4
Sing to God! Sing praises to his name!
Praise the one who rides through the plains of the Jordan River valley!
Yahweh is his name! Rejoice before him!
v 5
A father of the fatherless, a judge of the widows,
is God in the holy place where he lives.
v 6
God puts the lonely into families;
he brings out the prisoners with singing;
but the rebellious live in a parched land.
v 7
God, when you went out before your people,
when you marched through the wilderness,
Selah
v 8
The earth trembled;
the heavens also dropped rain in God’s presence,
in the presence of God when he came to Sinai, in the presence of God, the God of Israel.
v 9
You, God, sent a plentiful rain;
you strengthened your inheritance when it was weary.
Your people lived in it;
You, God, gave from your goodness to the poor.
The Lord gave the orders,
and those who announced them were a great army.
Kings of armies flee, they flee,
and the women waiting at home divide the plunder:
doves covered with silver
with wings of yellow gold.
When some of you people stayed among the sheepfolds, why did you do this?
The Almighty scattered kings there,
it was as when it snowed on Mount Zalmon.
A mighty mountain is the hill country of Bashan;
a high mountain is the hill country of Bashan.
Why do you look in envy, you high hill country,
at the mountain which God desires for the place he will live?
Indeed, Yahweh will live in it forever.
The chariots of God are twenty thousand, thousands upon thousands;
the Lord is among them in the holy place, as at Sinai.
You have ascended on high; you have led away captives;
you have received gifts from among men,
even from those who fought against you,
so that you, Yahweh God, might live there.
Blessed be the Lord, who daily bears our burdens,
the God who is our salvation.
Selah
Our God is a God who saves;
Yahweh the Lord is the one who is able to rescue us from death.
But God will strike through the heads of his enemies,
through the hairy scalps of those who walk in offenses against him.
The Lord said, “I will bring my enemies back from Bashan;
I will bring them back from the depths of the sea
so that you may crush your enemies, dipping your foot in blood,
and so that the tongues of your dogs may have their share from your enemies.”
They have seen your processions, God,
the processions of my God, my King, into the holy place.
The singers went first, the minstrels followed after,
and in the middle were the unmarried girls playing tambourines.
Bless God in the assemblies;
praise Yahweh, you who are from the fountain
>> Footnote
of Israel.
There is first Benjamin, the smallest tribe,
then the leaders of Judah and their multitudes,
the leaders of Zebulun and the leaders of Naphtali.
Your God, Israel, has decreed your strength;
reveal to us your power, God, as you have revealed it in times past.
Reveal your power to us from your temple at Jerusalem,
where kings bring gifts to you.
Shout in battle against the wild beasts in the reeds,
against the peoples, that multitude of bulls and calves.
Humiliate them and make them bring you gifts;
scatter the peoples who love to wage war.
Princes will come out of Egypt;
Cush will hurry to reach out with her hands to God.
Sing to God, you kingdoms of the earth;
Selah
Sing praises to Yahweh.
To him who rides on the heaven of heavens, which exist from ancient times;
see, he lifts up his voice with power.
Ascribe strength to God;
his majesty is over Israel,
and his strength is in the skies.
God, you are fearsome in your holy place;
the God of Israel—he gives strength and power to his people.
Blessed be God.
For the chief musician; set to Shoshannim. A psalm of David.
v 1
Save me, God;
for the waters have put my life in danger.
v 2
I sink in deep mire, where there is no place to stand;
I have come into deep waters, where the floods flow over me.
v 3
I am weary with my crying; my throat is dry;
my eyes fail while I wait for my God.
v 4
Those who hate me without a cause are more than the hairs on my head;
those who would cut me off, being my enemies for wrong reasons, are mighty;
what I did not steal, I have to give back.
v 5
God, you know my foolishness,
and my sins are not hidden from you.
v 6
Let not those who hope in you be put to shame because of me, Lord Yahweh of hosts;
let not those who seek you be brought to dishonor because of me, God of Israel.
v 7
For your sake I have borne rebuke;
shame has covered my face.
v 8
I have become a stranger to my brothers,
an alien to my mother’s children.
v 9
For the zeal of your house has eaten me up,
and the rebukes of those who rebuke you have fallen on me.
When I wept and did not eat food,
they insulted me.
When I made sackcloth my clothing,
I became the object of a proverb to them.
Those who sit in the city gate talk about me;
I am a song of drunkards.
But as for me, my prayer is to you, Yahweh, at a time that you will accept;
answer me in the trustworthiness of your salvation.
Pull me out of the mire, and do not let me sink;
let me be taken away from those who hate me and rescued out of the deep waters.
Do not let the floods of water overwhelm me,
neither let the deep swallow me up.
Do not let the pit shut its mouth on me.
Answer me, Yahweh, for your covenant faithfulness is good;
because your mercies for me are many, turn to me.
Do not hide your face from your servant,
for I am in distress; answer me quickly.
Come to me and redeem me.
Because of my enemies, ransom me.
You know my rebuke, my shame, and my dishonor;
my adversaries are all before you.
Rebuke has broken my heart; I am full of heaviness;
I looked for someone to take pity, but there was none;
I looked for comforters, but I found none.
They gave me poison for my food;
in my thirst they gave me vinegar to drink.
Let their table before them become a snare;
when they think they are in safety, let it become a trap.
Let their eyes be darkened so that they cannot see;
and always make their loins shake.
Pour out your indignation on them,
and let the fierceness of your anger overtake them.
Let their place be a desolation;
let no one live in their tents.
For they persecuted the one you struck down.
They repeated the account of the pain of those you have wounded.
Accuse them of having committed iniquity after iniquity;
do not let them come into your righteous victory.
Let them be blotted out of the Book of Life
and not be written down along with the righteous.
But I am poor and sorrowful;
let your salvation, God, set me up on high.
I will praise the name of God with a song
and will exalt him with thanksgiving.
That will please Yahweh better than an ox
or a bull that has horns and hooves.
The meek have seen it and are glad;
you who seek after God, let your hearts live.
For Yahweh hears the needy
and does not despise his prisoners.
Let heaven and earth praise him,
the seas and everything that moves in them.
For God will save Zion and will rebuild the cities of Judah;
the people will live there and have it as a possession.
His servants’ descendants will inherit it;
and those who love his name will live there.
For the chief musician. A psalm of David; to bring to remembrance.
v 1
Save me, God!
Yahweh, come quickly and help me.
v 2
Let those who try to take my life
be ashamed and humiliated;
let them be turned back and brought to dishonor,
those who take pleasure in my pain.
v 3
Let them be turned back because of their shame,
those who say, “Aha, aha.”
v 4
Let all those who seek you rejoice and be glad in you;
let those who love your salvation always say,
“May God be praised.”
v 5
But I am poor and needy;
hurry to me, God;
you are my help and you rescue me.
Yahweh, do not delay.
v 1
In you, Yahweh, I take refuge;
let me never be put to shame.
v 2
Rescue me and make me safe in your righteousness;
turn your ear to me and save me.
v 3
Be to me a rock for refuge where I may always go;
you have given a command to save me,
for you are my rock and my fortress.
v 4
Rescue me, my God, out of the hand of the wicked,
out of the hand of the unrighteous and cruel.
v 5
For you are my hope, Lord Yahweh.
I have trusted in you ever since I was a child.
v 6
By you I have been supported from the womb;
you are he who took me out of my mother’s belly;
my praise will be always about you.
v 7
I am an example to many people;
you are my strong refuge.
v 8
My mouth will be filled with your praise,
all the day with your honor.
v 9
Do not throw me away in my time of old age;
do not abandon me when my strength fails.
For my enemies are talking about me;
those who watch for my life are plotting together.
They say, “God has forsaken him;
pursue and take him, for there is no one to save him.”
God, do not be far from me;
my God, hurry to help me.
Let them be put to shame and destroyed, those who are hostile to my life;
let them be covered with rebuke and dishonor, those who seek my hurt.
But I will always hope in you
and will praise you more and more.
My mouth will tell about your righteousness
and your salvation all the day,
although I cannot understand it.
I will come with the mighty acts of the Lord Yahweh;
I will make mention of your righteousness, yours alone.
God, you have taught me from my youth;
even now I declare your wonderful deeds.
Indeed, even when I am old and gray-headed, God, do not forsake me,
as I have been declaring your strength to the next generation,
your power to everyone who is to come.
Your righteousness also, God, is very high;
you who have done great things, God, who is like you?
You who made me see many troubles
will revive us again
and will bring us up again from the depths of the earth.
May you increase my honor;
turn again and comfort me.
I will also give thanks to you with the harp
for your trustworthiness, my God;
to you I will sing praises with the harp,
Holy One of Israel.
My lips will shout for joy when I sing praises to you—
even my soul, which you have redeemed.
My tongue will also talk about your righteousness all day long;
for they have been put to shame and are confused, those who sought my hurt.
A psalm of Solomon.
v 1
Give the king your righteous decrees, God,
your righteousness to the king’s son.
v 2
May he judge your people with righteousness
and your poor with justice.
v 3
May the mountains produce peace for the people;
may the hills produce righteousness.
v 4
May he judge the poor of the people;
may he save the children of the needy
and break in pieces the oppressor.
v 5
May they honor you while the sun endures,
and as long as the moon lasts throughout all generations.
v 6
May he come down like rain on the mown grass,
like showers that water the earth.
v 7
May the righteous flourish in his days,
and may there be an abundance of peace till the moon is no more.
v 8
May he have dominion from sea to sea,
and from the River to the ends of the earth.
v 9
May those who live in the wilderness bow down before him;
may his enemies lick the dust.
May the kings of Tarshish and of the islands render tribute;
may the kings of Sheba and Seba offer gifts.
Indeed, may all kings fall down before him;
may all nations serve him.
For he helps the needy person who cries out
and the poor person who has no other helper.
He has pity on the poor and needy,
and he saves the lives of needy people.
He redeems their lives from oppression and violence,
and their blood is precious in his sight.
May he live! May the gold of Sheba be given to him.
May people always pray for him;
may God bless him all day long.
May there be abundance of grain in the land;
on the mountaintops may their crops wave.
May the fruit of it be like Lebanon;
may the people flourish in the cities like the grass of the field.
May his name endure forever;
may his name continue as long as the sun;
may people be blessed in him;
may all nations call him blessed.
May Yahweh God, the God of Israel, be blessed,
who alone does wonderful things.
May his glorious name be blessed forever,
and may the whole earth be filled with his glory.
Amen and Amen.
The prayers of David son of Jesse are finished.
>> Heading
A psalm of Asaph.
v 1
Surely God is good to Israel,
to those with a pure heart.
v 2
But as for me, my feet almost slipped;
my feet almost slipped out from under me
v 3
because I was envious of the arrogant
when I saw the prosperity of the wicked.
v 4
For they have no pain until their death,
but they are strong and well fed.
v 5
They are free from the burdens of other men;
they are not afflicted like other men.
v 6
Pride adorns them like a necklace around their neck;
violence clothes them like a robe.
v 7
Out of such blindness comes sin;
evil thoughts pass through their hearts.
v 8
They mock and speak wickedly;
in their arrogance they threaten oppression.
v 9
They set their mouth against the heavens,
and their tongues march through the earth.
Therefore his people turn to them
and abundant waters are drained out.
They say, “How does God know?
Is there knowledge with the Most High?”
Take notice: these people are wicked;
they are always carefree, becoming richer and richer.
Surely it is in vain that I have guarded my heart
and washed my hands in innocence.
For all the day long I have been afflicted
and disciplined every morning.
If I had said, “I will say these things,”
then I would have betrayed this generation of your children.
Though I tried to understand these things,
it was too difficult for me.
Then I went into God’s sanctuary
and came to understand their fate.
Surely you put them in slippery places;
you bring them down to ruin.
How they become a wilderness in a moment!
They come to an end and are finished in awful terrors.
They are like a dream after one wakes up;
Lord, when you arise, you will think nothing of those dreams.
For my heart was grieved,
and I was deeply wounded.
I was ignorant and lacked insight;
I was like a senseless animal before you.
Yet I am always with you;
you hold my right hand.
You will guide me with your advice
and afterward receive me to glory.
Whom have I in heaven but you?
There is no one on earth that I desire but you.
My flesh and my heart grow weak,
but God is the strength of my heart forever.
Those who are far from you will perish;
you will destroy all those who are unfaithful to you.
But as for me, all I need to do is to approach God.
I have made the Lord Yahweh my refuge.
I will declare all your deeds.
A maschil of Asaph.
v 1
God, why have you rejected us forever?
Why does your anger burn against the sheep of your pasture?
v 2
Call to mind your people, whom you purchased in ancient times,
the tribe whom you have redeemed to be your own heritage,
and Mount Zion, where you live.
v 3
Come look at the complete ruins,
all the damage that the enemy has done in the holy place.
v 4
Your adversaries roared in the middle of your appointed place;
they set up their battle flags.
v 5
They hacked away with axes
as in a thick forest.
v 6
They smashed and broke down all the engravings;
they broke them with axes and hammers.
v 7
They set your sanctuary on fire;
they desecrated where you live, knocking it to the ground.
v 8
They said in their hearts, “We will destroy them all.”
They burned up all of your meeting places in the land.
v 9
We do not see any more signs;
there is no prophet any more,
and no one among us knows how long this will last.
How long, God, will the enemy throw insults at you?
Will the enemy blaspheme your name forever?
Why do you hold back your hand, your right hand?
Take your right hand from your garment and destroy them.
Yet God has been my king from ancient times,
bringing salvation on the earth.
You divided the sea by your strength;
you smashed the heads of the sea monsters in the waters.
You crushed the heads of leviathan;
you fed him to those living in the wilderness.
You broke open springs and streams;
you dried up flowing rivers.
The day is yours, and the night is yours also;
you set the sun and moon in place.
You have set all the borders of the earth;
you have made summer and winter.
Call to mind how the enemy hurled insults at you, Yahweh,
and that a foolish people has blasphemed your name.
Do not give the life of your dove to a wild animal.
Do not forget forever the life of your oppressed people.
Remember your covenant,
for the dark regions of the land are full of places of violence.
Do not let the oppressed be turned back in shame;
let the poor and oppressed praise your name.
Arise, God; defend your own honor;
call to mind how fools insult you all day long.
Do not forget the voice of your adversaries
or the uproar of those who continually defy you.
For the chief musician; set to Al Tashheth. A psalm of Asaph, a song.
v 1
We give thanks to you, God;
we give thanks, for you reveal your presence;
people tell of your wondrous works.
v 2
At the appointed time I will judge fairly.
v 3
Though the earth and all the inhabitants shake in fear,
I make steady the earth’s pillars.
Selah
v 4
I said to the arrogant, “Do not be arrogant,”
and to the wicked, “Do not lift up the horn.
v 5
Do not lift up your horn to the heights;
do not speak with an insolent neck.”
v 6
It is not from the east or from the west,
and it is not from the wilderness that lifting up comes.
v 7
But God is the judge;
he brings down and he lifts up.
v 8
For Yahweh holds in his hand a cup of foaming wine,
which is mixed with spices, and pours it out.
Surely all the wicked of the earth will drink it to the last drop.
v 9
But I will continually tell what you have done;
I will sing praises to the God of Jacob.
He says, “I will cut off all the horns of the wicked,
but the horns of the righteous will be raised up.”
For the chief musician, on stringed instruments. A psalm of Asaph, a song.
v 1
God has made himself known in Judah;
his name is great in Israel.
v 2
His tent is in Salem;
his dwelling place is in Zion.
v 3
There he broke the arrows of the bow,
the shield, the sword, and the other weapons of war.
Selah
v 4
You shine brightly and reveal your glory,
as you descend from the mountains, where you killed your victims.
v 5
The bravehearted were plundered;
they fell asleep.
All the warriors were helpless.
v 6
At your rebuke, God of Jacob,
both rider and horse fell asleep.
v 7
You, yes you, are to be feared;
who can stand in your sight when you are angry?
v 8
From heaven you made your judgment heard;
the earth was afraid and silent
v 9
when you, God, arose to execute judgment
and to save all the oppressed of the earth.
Selah
Surely your angry judgment against humanity will bring you praise;
you gird yourself with what is left of your anger.
Make vows to Yahweh your God and keep them.
May all who surround him bring gifts to him who is to be feared.
He cuts off the spirit of the princes;
he is feared by the kings of the earth.
For the chief musician; after the manner of Jeduthun. A psalm of Asaph.
v 1
I will call out with my voice to God;
I will call with my voice to God, and my God will hear me.
v 2
In the day of my trouble I sought the Lord;
at night I stretched my hands out, and they would not become tired.
My soul refused to be comforted.
v 3
I thought of God as I groaned;
I thought about him as I grew faint.
Selah
v 4
You held my eyes open;
I was too troubled to speak.
v 5
I thought about the days of old,
about times long past.
v 6
During the night I called to mind the song I once sang.
I thought carefully
and tried to understand what had happened.
v 7
Will the Lord reject me forever?
Will he never again show me favor?
v 8
Was his covenant faithfulness gone forever?
Had his promise failed forever?
v 9
Had God forgotten to be gracious?
Had his anger shut off his compassion?
Selah
I said, “This is my sorrow:
the changing of the right hand of the Most High toward us.”
But I will call to mind your deeds, Yahweh;
I will think about your wonderful deeds of old.
I will ponder all your deeds
and will reflect on them.
Your way, God, is holy;
what god compares to our great God?
You are the God who does wonders;
you have revealed your strength among the peoples.
You gave your people victory by your great power—
the descendants of Jacob and Joseph.
Selah
The waters saw you, God;
the waters saw you, and they were afraid;
the depths trembled.
The clouds poured down water;
the cloudy skies gave voice;
your arrows flew about.
Your thunderous voice was heard in the wind;
the lightning lit up the world;
the earth trembled and shook.
Your path went through the sea
and your way through the surging waters,
but your footprints were not seen.
You led your people like a flock
by the hand of Moses and Aaron.
A maschil of Asaph.
v 1
Hear my teaching, my people,
listen to the words of my mouth.
v 2
I will open my mouth in parables;
I will sing about hidden things about the past.
v 3
These are things that we have heard and learned,
things that our ancestors have told us.
v 4
We will not keep them from their descendants.
We will tell the next generation about the praiseworthy deeds of Yahweh,
his strength, and the wonders that he has done.
v 5
For he established covenant decrees in Jacob
and appointed a law in Israel.
He commanded our ancestors
that they were to teach them to their children.
v 6
He commanded this so that the generation to come might know his decrees, the children not yet born,
who should tell them in turn to their own children.
v 7
Then they would place their hope in God
and not forget his deeds
but keep his commandments.
v 8
Then they would not be like their ancestors,
who were a stubborn and rebellious generation,
a generation whose hearts were not right,
and whose spirits were not committed and faithful to God.
v 9
The Ephraimites were armed with bows,
but they turned back on the day of battle.
They did not keep the covenant with God,
and they refused to obey his law.
They forgot his deeds,
the wonderful things that he had shown them.
They forgot the marvelous things he did in the sight of their ancestors
in the land of Egypt, in the land of Zoan.
He divided the sea and led them across it;
he made the waters to stand like walls.
In the daytime he led them with a cloud
and all the night with the light of fire.
He split the rocks in the wilderness,
and he gave them water abundantly, enough to fill the depths of the sea.
He made streams flow out of the rock
and made the water flow like rivers.
Yet they continued to sin against him,
rebelling against the Most High in the wilderness.
They challenged God in their hearts
by asking for food to satisfy their appetites.
They spoke against God;
they said, “Can God really lay out a table for us in the wilderness?
See, when he struck the rock, waters gushed out
and streams overflowed.
But can he give bread also?
Will he provide meat for his people?”
When Yahweh heard this, he was angry;
so his fire burned against Jacob,
and his anger attacked Israel,
because they did not believe in God
and did not trust in his salvation.
Yet he commanded the skies above
and opened the doors of the sky.
He rained down manna for them to eat,
and gave them the grain from heaven.
People ate the bread of angels.
He sent them food in abundance.
He caused the east wind to blow in the sky,
and by his power he guided the south wind.
He rained down meat on them like dust,
birds as numerous as the sands of the sea.
They fell in the middle of their camp,
all around their tents.
So they ate and were full.
He gave them what they craved.
But they had not yet filled up;
their food was still in their mouths.
Then God’s anger attacked them
and killed the strongest of them.
He brought down the young men of Israel.
Despite this, they continued to sin
and did not believe his wonderful deeds.
Therefore God cut short their days;
their years were filled with terror.
Whenever God afflicted them, they would start to seek him,
and they would return and look earnestly for him.
They would call to mind that God was their rock
and that the Most High God was their rescuer.
But they would flatter him with their mouth
and lie to him with their words.
For their hearts were not firmly fixed on him,
and they were not faithful to his covenant.
Yet he, being merciful, forgave their iniquity and did not destroy them.
Yes, many times he held back his anger
and did not stir up all his wrath.
He called to mind that they were made of flesh,
a wind that passes away and does not return.
How often they rebelled against him in the wilderness
and grieved him in the barren regions!
Again and again they challenged God
and offended the Holy One of Israel.
They did not think about his power,
how he had rescued them from the enemy
when he performed his terrifying signs in Egypt
and his wonders in the region of Zoan.
He turned the Egyptians’ rivers to blood
so that they could not drink from their streams.
He sent swarms of flies that devoured them
and frogs that overran their land.
He gave their crops to the grasshopper
and their labor to the locust.
He destroyed their vines with hail
and their sycamore trees with more hail.
He rained hail on their cattle
and hurled lightning bolts at their livestock.
The fierceness of his anger lashed out against them.
He sent wrath, fury, and trouble
like agents who bring disaster.
He leveled a path for his anger;
he did not spare them from death
but gave them over to the plague.
He killed all the firstborn in Egypt,
the firstborn of their strength in the tents of Ham.
He led his own people out like sheep
and guided them through the wilderness like a flock.
He led them secure and unafraid,
but the sea overwhelmed their enemies.
Then he brought them to the border of his holy land,
to this mountain that his right hand acquired.
He drove out the nations from before them
and assigned them their inheritance.
He settled the tribes of Israel in their tents.
Yet they challenged and defied the Most High God
and did not keep his solemn commands.
They were unfaithful and acted treacherously like their fathers;
they were as undependable as a faulty bow.
For they made him angry with their high places
and provoked him to jealous anger with their idols.
When God heard this, he was angry
and completely rejected Israel.
He abandoned the sanctuary of Shiloh,
the tent where he had lived among people.
He allowed his strength to be captured
and gave his glory into the enemy’s hand.
He handed his people over to the sword,
and he was angry with his heritage.
Fire devoured their young men,
and their young women had no wedding songs.
Their priests fell by the sword,
and their widows could not weep.
Then the Lord awakened as one from sleep,
like a warrior who shouts because of wine.
He drove his adversaries back;
he put them to everlasting shame.
He rejected the tent of Joseph,
and he did not chose the tribe of Ephraim.
He chose the tribe of Judah
and Mount Zion that he loved.
He built his sanctuary like the heavens,
like the earth that he has established forever.
He chose David, his servant,
and took him from the sheepfolds.
He took him from following the ewes with their young, and he brought him
to be shepherd of Jacob, his people, and of Israel, his heritage.
David shepherded them with the integrity of his heart,
and he guided them with the skill of his hands.
A psalm of Asaph.
v 1
God, foreign nations have come into your inheritance;
they have defiled your holy temple;
they have turned Jerusalem into a heap of ruins.
v 2
They have given the dead bodies of your servants as food to the birds of the skies,
the bodies of your faithful ones to the beasts of the earth.
v 3
They have shed their blood like water around Jerusalem,
and there was none to bury them.
v 4
We have become a reproach for our neighbors,
mocking and derision to those who are around us.
v 5
How long, Yahweh? Will you stay angry forever?
How long will your jealous anger burn like fire?
v 6
Pour out your wrath on the nations that do not know you
and on the kingdoms that do not call upon your name.
v 7
For they have devoured Jacob
and destroyed his villages.
v 8
Do not hold the sins of our forefathers against us;
may your merciful actions come to us,
for we are very low.
v 9
Help us, God of our salvation, for the sake of the glory of your name;
save us and forgive our sins for your name’s sake.
Why should the nations say, “Where is their God?”
May the blood of your servants that was shed
be avenged on the nations before our eyes.
May the groans of the prisoners come before you;
with the greatness of your power keep the children of death alive.
Pay back into the laps of our neighboring countries seven times as much
as the insults with which they have insulted you, Lord.
So we your people and sheep of your pasture
will give you thanks forever.
We will tell your praises to all generations.
For the chief musician, set to the Shoshannim Eduth style. A psalm of Asaph.
v 1
Pay attention, Shepherd of Israel,
you who lead Joseph like a flock;
you who sit above the cherubim, shine on us!
v 2
In the sight of Ephraim and Benjamin and Manasseh, stir up your power;
come and save us.
v 3
God, restore us;
make your face shine on us, and we will be saved.
v 4
Yahweh God of hosts,
how long will you be angry at your people when they pray?
v 5
You have fed them with the bread of tears
and given them tears to drink in great quantities.
v 6
You make us something for our neighbors to argue over,
and our enemies laugh about us among themselves.
v 7
God of hosts, restore us;
make your face shine on us, and we will be saved.
v 8
You brought a vine out of Egypt;
you drove out nations and transplanted it.
v 9
You cleared the land for it;
it took root and filled the land.
The mountains were covered with its shade,
the cedars of God by its branches.
It sent out its branches as far as the sea
and its shoots to the Euphrates River.
Why have you broken down its walls
so that all who pass by along the road pluck its fruit?
The boars out of the forest ruin it,
and the beasts of the field feed on it.
Turn back, God of hosts;
look down from heaven and take notice and take care of this vine.
This is the root that your right hand planted,
the shoot that you made to grow.
It has been burned and cut down;
they perish because of your rebuke.
May your hand be on the man of your right hand,
on the son of man whom you made strong for yourself.
Then we will not turn away from you;
revive us, and we will call on your name.
Yahweh God of hosts, restore us;
make your face shine on us, and we will be saved.
For the chief musician; set to the Gittith style. A psalm of Asaph.
v 1
Sing aloud to God our strength;
shout out for joy to the God of Jacob.
v 2
Sing a song and play the tambourine,
the pleasant lyre with the harp.
v 3
Blow the trumpet on the day of the new moon,
on the day of the full moon, when our feast day begins.
v 4
For it is a statute for Israel,
a decree given by the God of Jacob.
v 5
He issued it as a regulation in Joseph
when he went against the land of Egypt,
where I heard a voice that I did not recognize:
v 6
“I removed the burden from his shoulder;
his hands were freed from holding the basket.
v 7
In your distress you called out, and I helped you;
I answered you from a dark thundercloud.
I tested you at the waters of Meribah.
Selah
v 8
Listen, my people, for I will warn you,
Israel, if you would only listen to me!
v 9
There must be no foreign god among you;
you must not worship any foreign god.
I am Yahweh your God,
who brought you out of the land of Egypt.
Open your mouth wide, and I will fill it.
But my people did not listen to my words;
Israel did not obey me.
So I gave them over to their own stubborn way
so that they might do what seemed right to them.
Oh, that my people would listen to me;
oh, that my people would walk in my paths.
Then I would quickly subdue their enemies
and turn my hand against their oppressors.
May those who hate Yahweh cringe in fear before him!
May they be humiliated forever.
I would feed Israel with the finest wheat;
I would satisfy you with honey out of the rock.”
A psalm of Asaph.
v 1
God stands in the divine assembly;
in the midst of the gods he renders judgment.
v 2
How long will you judge unjustly
and show favoritism to the wicked?
Selah
v 3
Defend the poor and fatherless;
maintain the rights of the afflicted and destitute.
v 4
Rescue the poor and needy;
take them out of the hand of the wicked.
v 5
They neither know nor understand;
they wander around in the darkness;
all the foundations of the earth crumble.
v 6
I said, “You are gods,
and all of you sons of the Most High.
v 7
Nevertheless you will die like men
and fall like one of the princes.”
v 8
Arise, God, judge the earth,
for you have an inheritance in all the nations.
A song. A psalm of Asaph.
v 1
God, do not be silent!
Do not ignore us and remain unmoved, God.
v 2
Look, your enemies are making a commotion,
and those who hate you have raised their heads.
v 3
They conspire against your people
and plan together against your protected ones.
v 4
They have said, “Come, and let us destroy them as a nation.
Then the name of Israel will no longer be remembered.”
v 5
They schemed together with one strategy;
they made an alliance against you—
v 6
the tents of Edom and the Ishmaelites,
of Moab and the Hagrites,
v 7
Gebal, Ammon, Amalek;
and also Philistia and the inhabitants of Tyre.
v 8
Assyria also has joined with them;
they have become an arm for the descendants of Lot.
Selah
v 9
Do to them as you did to Midian,
as you did to Sisera and to Jabin at the Kishon River.
They perished at Endor
and became like manure for the earth.
Make their nobles like Oreb and Zeeb,
and all their princes like Zebah and Zalmunna.
They said, “Let us take for ourselves
the pastures of God.”
My God, make them like the whirling dust,
like chaff before the wind,
like the fire that burns the forest,
and like the flame that sets the mountains on fire.
Chase them with your strong wind,
and terrify them with your windstorm.
Fill their faces with shame
so that they might seek your name, Yahweh.
May they be put to shame and be terrified forever;
may they perish in disgrace.
Then they will know that you alone, Yahweh,
are the Most High over all the earth.
For the chief musician; set to the Gittith style. A psalm of the sons of Korah.
v 1
How lovely is the place where you live,
Yahweh of hosts!
v 2
I long for the courts of Yahweh, my desire for it has made me exhausted.
My heart and all of my being call out to the living God.
v 3
Even the sparrow has found her a house
and the swallow a nest for herself where she may lay her young
near your altars, Yahweh of hosts,
my King, and my God.
v 4
Blessed are they who live in your house;
they praise you continually.
Selah
v 5
Blessed is the man whose strength is in you,
in whose heart are the highways up to Zion.
v 6
Passing through the Valley of Tears, they find springs of water to drink.
The early rains cover it with blessings.
>> Footnote
v 7
They go from strength to strength;
every one of them appears before God in Zion.
v 8
Yahweh God of hosts, hear my prayer;
God of Jacob, listen to what I am saying!
Selah
v 9
God, watch over our shield;
show concern for your anointed.
For one day in your courts is better than a thousand elsewhere.
I would rather be a doorkeeper in the house of my God,
than to live within the tents of the wicked.
For Yahweh God is our sun and shield;
Yahweh will give grace and glory;
he does not withhold any good thing from those who walk in integrity.
Yahweh of hosts,
blessed is the man who trusts in you.
For the chief musician. A psalm of the sons of Korah.
v 1
Yahweh, you have showed favor to your land;
you have restored the well-being of Jacob.
v 2
You have forgiven the sin of your people;
you have covered all their sin.
Selah
v 3
You have withdrawn all your wrath;
you have turned back from your hot anger.
v 4
Restore us, God of our salvation,
and let go of your displeasure with us.
v 5
Will you be angry with us forever?
Will you remain angry throughout future generations?
v 6
Will you not revive us again?
Then your people will rejoice in you.
v 7
Show us your covenant faithfulness, Yahweh,
grant us your salvation.
v 8
I will listen to what Yahweh God says,
for he will make peace with his people, his faithful ones.
Yet they must not turn again to foolish ways.
v 9
Surely his salvation is near to those who fear him;
then glory will remain in our land.
Covenant faithfulness and trustworthiness have met together;
righteousness and peace have kissed each other.
Trustworthiness springs up from the ground,
and righteousness looks down from the sky.
Yes, Yahweh will give his good blessings,
and our land will yield its crops.
Righteousness will go before him
and make a way for his footsteps.
A prayer of David.
v 1
Listen, Yahweh, and answer me,
for I am poor and needy.
v 2
Protect me, for I am faithful;
my God, save your servant who trusts in you.
v 3
Be merciful to me, Lord,
for I cry out to you all day long.
v 4
Make your servant glad,
for to you, Lord, I lift up my soul.
v 5
You, Lord, are good, and ready to forgive,
and you show great mercy to all those who cry out to you.
v 6
Yahweh, listen to my prayer;
hear the sound of my pleas.
v 7
In the day of my trouble I call on you,
for you will answer me.
v 8
There is no one who compares to you among the gods, Lord.
There are no deeds like your deeds.
v 9
All the nations that you have made will come and bow before you, Lord.
They will honor your name.
For you are great and do wonderful things;
you only are God.
Teach me your ways, Yahweh. Then I will walk in your truth.
Unite my heart to reverence you.
Lord my God, I will praise you with my whole heart;
I will glorify your name forever.
For great is your covenant faithfulness toward me;
you have rescued my life from the depths of Sheol.
God, the arrogant have risen up against me.
A gang of violent men seek my life.
They have no regard for you.
But you, Lord, are a merciful and gracious God,
slow to anger, and abundant in covenant faithfulness and trustworthiness.
Turn toward me and have mercy on me;
give your strength to your servant;
save the son of your servant woman.
Show me a sign of your favor.
Then those who hate me will see it and be put to shame
because you, Yahweh, have helped me and comforted me.
A psalm of the sons of Korah; a song.
v 1
On the holy mount stands the city he founded;
v 2
Yahweh loves the gates of Zion
more than all the tents of Jacob.
v 3
Glorious things are said of you, city of God.
Selah
v 4
“I mention Rahab and Babylon to my followers.
See, there are Philistia, and Tyre, along with Cush—
and will say, ‘This one was born there.’”
v 5
Of Zion it will be said, “Each of these was born in her;
and the Most High himself will establish her.”
v 6
Yahweh writes in the census book of the nations,
“This one was born there.”
Selah
v 7
So also the singers and the dancers say together,
“All my fountains are in you.”
A song, a psalm of the sons of Korah; for the chief musician; set to the Mahalath Leannoth style. A maschil of Heman the Ezrahite.
v 1
Yahweh, God of my salvation,
I cry out day and night before you.
v 2
Listen to my prayer;
pay attention to my cry.
v 3
For I am filled with troubles,
and my life has reached Sheol.
v 4
People treat me like those who go down into the pit;
I am a man with no strength.
v 5
I am abandoned among the dead;
I am like the dead who lie in the grave,
about whom you care no more
because they are cut off from your power.
v 6
You place me in the lowest part of the pit,
in the dark and deep places.
v 7
Your wrath lies heavy on me,
and all your waves crash over me.
Selah
v 8
Because of you, my acquaintances avoid me.
You have made me a shocking sight to them.
I am hemmed in and I cannot escape.
v 9
My eyes grow weary from trouble;
All day long I call out to you, Yahweh;
I spread out my hands to you.
Will you do wonders for the dead?
Will those who have died rise and praise you?
Selah
Will your covenant faithfulness be proclaimed in the grave,
your loyalty in the place of the dead?
Will your wonderful deeds be known in the darkness,
or your righteousness in the place of forgetfulness?
But I cry to you, Yahweh;
in the morning my prayer comes before you.
Yahweh, why do you reject me?
Why do you hide your face from me?
I have always been afflicted and on the verge of death since my youth.
I have suffered from your terrors; I am in despair.
Your angry actions have passed over me,
and your terrifying deeds have annihilated me.
They surround me like water all the day long;
they have all encircled me.
You have removed every friend and acquaintance from me.
My only acquaintance is the darkness.
A maschil of Ethan the Ezrahite.
v 1
I will sing of Yahweh’s acts of covenant faithfulness forever.
I will proclaim your truthfulness to future generations.
v 2
For I have said, “Covenant faithfulness has been established forever;
your truthfulness you have established in the heavens.”
v 3
“I have made a covenant with my chosen one,
I have made an oath to David my servant.
v 4
I will establish your descendants forever,
and I will establish your throne through all generations.”
Selah
v 5
The heavens praise your wonders, Yahweh;
your truthfulness is praised in the assembly of the holy ones.
v 6
For who in the skies can be compared to Yahweh?
Who among the sons of the gods is like Yahweh?
v 7
He is a God who is greatly honored in the council of the holy ones
and is awesome among all who surround him.
v 8
Yahweh God of hosts,
who is strong like you, Yahweh?
Your truthfulness surrounds you.
v 9
You rule the raging sea;
when the waves surge, you calm them.
You crushed Rahab as one who is killed.
You scattered your enemies with your strong arm.
The heavens belong to you, and the earth also.
You made the world and all it contains.
You created the north and the south.
Tabor and Hermon rejoice in your name.
You have a mighty arm
and a strong hand, and your right hand is high.
Righteousness and justice are the foundation of your throne.
Covenant faithfulness and trustworthiness come before you.
Blessed are the people who worship you!
Yahweh, they walk in the light of your face.
They rejoice in your name all day long,
and in your righteousness they exalt you.
You are their majestic strength,
and by your favor we are victorious.
For our shield belongs to Yahweh;
our king belongs to the Holy One of Israel.
Long ago you spoke in a vision to your faithful ones;
>> Footnote
you said, “I have set a crown on a mighty one.”
>> Footnote
I have raised up one chosen from among the people.
I have chosen David my servant;
with my holy oil have I anointed him.
My hand will support him;
my arm will strengthen him.
No enemy will deceive him;
no son of wickedness will oppress him.
I will crush his enemies before him;
I will kill those who hate him.
My truth and my covenant faithfulness will be with him;
by my name he will be victorious.
I will place his hand over the sea
and his right hand over the rivers.
He will call out to me, ‘You are my Father,
my God, and the rock of my salvation.’
I also will place him as my firstborn son,
the most exalted of the kings of the earth.
I will extend my covenant faithfulness to him forever;
and my covenant with him will be secure.
I will make his descendants endure forever
and his throne as enduring as the skies above.
If his children forsake my law
and do not walk in my regulations,
if they break my rules
and do not keep my commands,
then will I punish their rebellion with a rod
and their iniquity with blows.
But I will not remove my steadfast love from him
or be unfaithful to my promise.
I will not break my covenant
or change the words of my lips.
Once and for all I have sworn by my holiness—
I will not lie to David:
his descendants will continue forever
and his throne as long as the sun before me.
It will be established forever like the moon,
the faithful witness in the sky.”
Selah
But you have refused and rejected;
you have been angry with your anointed king.
You have renounced the covenant of your servant.
You have desecrated his crown on the ground.
You have broken down all his walls.
You have ruined his strongholds.
All who pass by have robbed him.
He has become an object of disgust to his neighbors.
You have raised the right hand of his enemies;
you have made all his enemies rejoice.
You turn back the edge of his sword
and have not made him stand when in battle.
You have brought his splendor to an end;
you have brought down his throne to the ground.
You have shortened the days of his youth.
You have covered him with shame.
Selah
How long, Yahweh? Will you hide yourself, forever?
How long will your anger burn like fire?
Oh, think about how short my time is,
and for what uselessness you have created all the children of mankind!
Who can live and not die,
or rescue his own life from the hand of Sheol?
Selah
Lord, where are your former acts of covenant faithfulness
that you swore to David in your truthfulness?
Call to mind, Lord, the mocking directed against your servants
and how I bear in my heart so many insults from the nations.
Your enemies hurl insults, Yahweh;
they mock the footsteps of your anointed one.
Blessed be Yahweh forever.
Amen and Amen.
>> Heading
A prayer of Moses the man of God.
v 1
Lord, you have been our refuge
throughout all generations.
v 2
Before the mountains were formed,
or you formed the earth and the world,
from everlasting to everlasting, you are God.
v 3
You return man to dust,
and you say, “Return, you descendants of mankind.”
v 4
For a thousand years in your sight
are as yesterday when it is past,
and as a watch in the night.
v 5
You sweep them away as with a flood and they sleep;
in the morning they are like the grass that sprouts up.
v 6
In the morning it blooms and grows up;
in the evening it withers and dries up.
v 7
Truly, we are consumed in your anger,
and in your wrath we are terrified.
v 8
You have set our iniquities before you,
our hidden sins in the light of your presence.
v 9
Our life passes away under your wrath;
our years quickly pass like a sigh.
Our years are seventy,
or even eighty if we are healthy;
but even our best years are marked by trouble and sorrow.
Yes, they pass quickly, and we fly away.
Who knows the intensity of your anger,
and your wrath that is equal to the fear of you?
So teach us to consider our life
so that we might live wisely.
Turn back, Yahweh! How long will it be?
Have pity on your servants.
Satisfy us in the morning with your covenant faithfulness
so that we may rejoice and be glad all our days.
Make us glad in proportion to the days you afflicted us
and to the years we have experienced trouble.
Let your servants see your work,
and let our children see your majesty.
May the favor of the Lord our God be ours;
prosper the work of our hands;
indeed, prosper the work of our hands.
v 1
He who lives in the shelter of the Most High
will stay in the shadow of the Almighty.
v 2
I will say of Yahweh, “He is my refuge and my fortress,
my God, in whom I trust.”
v 3
For he will rescue you from the snare of the hunter
and from the deadly plague.
v 4
He will cover you with his wings,
and under his wings you will find refuge.
His trustworthiness is a shield and protection.
v 5
You will not be afraid of terror in the night,
or of the arrow that flies by day,
v 6
or of the plague that roams around in the darkness,
or of the disease that comes at noontime.
v 7
A thousand may fall at your side
and ten thousand at your right hand,
but it will not reach you.
v 8
You will only observe
and see the punishment of the wicked.
v 9
For Yahweh is my refuge!
Make the Most High your refuge also.
No evil will overtake you;
no affliction will come near your home.
For he will direct his angels to protect you,
to guard you in all your ways.
They will lift you up with their hand
so that you will not hit your foot on a stone.
You will crush lions and adders under your feet;
you will trample on young lions and serpents.
Because he is devoted to me, I will rescue him.
I will protect him because he is loyal to me.
When he calls to me, I will answer him.
I will be with him in trouble;
I will give him victory and will honor him.
I will satisfy him with the length of his days,
and show him my salvation.
A psalm, a song for the Sabbath day.
v 1
It is a good thing to give thanks to Yahweh
and to sing praises to your name, Most High,
v 2
to proclaim your covenant faithfulness in the morning
and your truthfulness every night,
v 3
with a harp of ten strings
and with the melody of the lyre.
v 4
For you, Yahweh, have made me glad through your deeds.
I will sing for joy because of the deeds of your hands.
v 5
How great are your deeds, Yahweh!
Your thoughts are very deep.
v 6
A brutish person does not know,
nor does a fool understand this:
v 7
When the wicked sprout like the grass,
and even when all the evildoers thrive,
still they are doomed to eternal destruction.
v 8
But you, Yahweh, will reign forever.
v 9
Indeed, look at your enemies, Yahweh!
Indeed, look at your enemies. They will perish!
All those who do evil will be scattered.
You have lifted up my horn like the horn of the wild ox;
I am anointed with fresh oil.
My eyes have seen the downfall of my enemies;
my ears have heard of the doom of my evil foes.
The righteous will flourish like the palm tree;
they will grow like a cedar in Lebanon.
They are planted in the house of Yahweh;
they flourish in the courts of our God.
They bear fruit even when they are old;
they stay fresh and green,
to proclaim that Yahweh is just.
He is my rock, and there is no unrighteousness in him.
v 1
Yahweh reigns; he is robed in majesty;
Yahweh has clothed and girded himself with strength.
The world is firmly established; it cannot be moved.
v 2
Your throne is established from ancient times;
you are from everlasting.
v 3
The oceans rise, Yahweh;
they have lifted up their voice;
the oceans’ waves crash and roar.
v 4
Above the crashing of many waves,
the mighty breakers of the sea,
Yahweh on high is mighty.
v 5
Your solemn commands are very trustworthy;
holiness adorns your house,
Yahweh, for the length of your days.
v 1
Yahweh, God who avenges,
God who avenges, shine over us.
v 2
Rise up, judge of the earth,
give to the proud what they deserve.
v 3
How long will the wicked, Yahweh,
how long will the wicked rejoice?
v 4
They pour out their arrogant words;
all those who do evil boast.
v 5
They crush your people, Yahweh;
they afflict the nation that belongs to you.
v 6
They kill the widow and foreigner who lives in their country,
and they murder the fatherless.
v 7
They say, “Yahweh will not see,
the God of Jacob does not take notice of it.”
v 8
Understand, you stupid people!
You fools, when will you ever learn?
v 9
He who made the ear, does he not hear?
He who formed the eye, does he not see?
He who disciplines the nations, does he not correct?
He is the one who gives knowledge to man.
Yahweh knows the thoughts of men,
that they are vapor.
Blessed is the one whom you instruct, Yahweh,
the one whom you teach from your law.
You give him rest in times of trouble
until a pit is dug for the wicked.
For Yahweh will not forsake his people
or abandon his inheritance.
For judgment will again be righteous;
and all the upright in heart will follow it.
Who will rise up to defend me against the evildoers?
Who will stand up for me against the wicked?
Unless Yahweh had been my help,
I would soon be lying down in the place of silence.
When I said, “My foot is slipping,”
Your covenant faithfulness, Yahweh, held me up.
When cares within me are many, your consolations make me happy.
Can a throne of destruction be allied with you,
one who creates injustice by statute?
They conspire together to take the life of the righteous
and they condemn the innocent to death.
But Yahweh has been my high tower,
and my God has been the rock of my refuge.
He will bring on them their own iniquity
and will cut them off in their own wickedness.
Yahweh our God will cut them off.
v 1
Oh come, let us sing to Yahweh;
let us sing joyfully to the rock of our salvation.
v 2
Let us enter his presence with thanksgiving;
let us sing to him with psalms of praise.
v 3
For Yahweh is a great God
and a great King superior to all gods.
v 4
In his hand are the depths of the earth;
the heights of the mountains are his.
v 5
The sea is his, for he made it,
and his hands formed the dry land.
v 6
Oh come, let us worship and bow down;
let us kneel before Yahweh, our Creator:
v 7
For he is our God,
and we are the people of his pasture and the sheep of his hand.
Today—oh, that you would hear his voice!
v 8
“Do not harden your heart, as at Meribah,
or as on the day of Massah in the wilderness,
v 9
where your forefathers tested me
and tried me, though they had seen my deeds.
For forty years I was angry with that generation
and said, ‘This is a people whose hearts wander astray;
they have not known my ways.’
Therefore I vowed in my anger
that they would never enter into my resting place.”
v 1
Oh, sing to Yahweh a new song;
sing to Yahweh, all the earth.
v 2
Sing to Yahweh, bless his name;
announce his salvation day after day.
v 3
Declare his glory among the nations,
his marvelous deeds among all the nations.
v 4
For Yahweh is great and is to be praised greatly.
He is to be feared above all other gods.
v 5
For all the gods of the nations are idols,
but it is Yahweh who made the heavens.
v 6
Splendor and majesty are in his presence.
Strength and beauty are in his sanctuary.
v 7
Ascribe to Yahweh, you clans of peoples,
ascribe praise to Yahweh for his glory and strength.
v 8
Give to Yahweh the glory that his name deserves.
Bring an offering and come into his courts.
v 9
Bow down to Yahweh in the splendor of holiness;
tremble before him, all the earth.
Say among the nations, “Yahweh reigns.”
The world also is established; it cannot be shaken.
He judges the peoples fairly.
Let the heavens be glad, and let the earth rejoice;
let the sea roar and that which fills it shout with joy.
Let the fields rejoice and all that is in them.
Then let all the trees in the forest shout for joy
before Yahweh, for he is coming.
He is coming to judge the earth.
He will judge the world with righteousness
and the peoples with his faithfulness.
v 1
Yahweh reigns; let the earth rejoice;
let the many coastlands be glad.
v 2
Clouds and darkness surround him.
Righteousness and justice are the foundation of his throne.
v 3
Fire goes before him
and consumes his adversaries on every side.
v 4
His lightning lights up the world;
the earth sees and trembles.
v 5
The mountains melt like wax before Yahweh,
the Lord of the whole earth.
v 6
The skies declare his justice,
and all the nations see his glory.
v 7
All those who worship carved figures will be shamed,
those who boast in worthless idols—
bow down to him, all you gods!
v 8
Zion heard and was glad,
and the towns of Judah rejoiced
because of your righteous decrees, Yahweh.
v 9
For you, Yahweh, are most high above all the earth.
You are exalted far above all gods.
You who love Yahweh, hate evil!
He protects the lives of his faithful ones,
and he takes them out of the hand of the wicked.
Light is sown for the righteous
and gladness for those with honest hearts.
Be glad in Yahweh, you righteous;
and give thanks when you remember his holiness.
A psalm.
v 1
Oh, sing to Yahweh a new song,
for he has done marvelous things;
his right hand and his holy arm have given him victory.
v 2
Yahweh has made known his salvation;
he has openly showed his justice to all the nations.
v 3
He calls to mind his covenant loyalty and faithfulness for the house of Israel;
all the ends of the earth will see the victory of our God.
v 4
Shout for joy to Yahweh, all the earth;
burst into song, sing for joy, and sing praises.
v 5
Sing praises to Yahweh with the harp,
with the harp and melodious song.
v 6
With trumpets and the sound of the horn,
make a joyful noise before the King, Yahweh.
v 7
Let the sea shout and everything in it,
the world and those who live in it!
v 8
Let the rivers clap their hands,
and let the mountains shout for joy.
v 9
Yahweh is coming to judge the earth;
he will judge the world with righteousness
and the nations with fairness.
v 1
Yahweh reigns; let the nations tremble.
He sits enthroned above the cherubim; the earth quakes.
v 2
Yahweh is great in Zion;
he is exalted above all the nations.
v 3
Let them praise your great and awesome name;
he is holy.
v 4
The king is strong, and he loves justice.
You have established fairness;
you have done righteousness and justice in Jacob.
v 5
Praise Yahweh our God
and worship at his footstool.
He is holy.
v 6
Moses and Aaron were among his priests,
and Samuel was among those who called on his name.
They called to Yahweh, and he answered them.
v 7
He spoke to them from the pillar of cloud.
They kept his solemn commands
and the statutes that he gave them.
v 8
You answered them, Yahweh our God.
A forgiving God you were to them,
but one who punished their sinful deeds.
v 9
Praise Yahweh our God,
and worship at his holy hill,
for Yahweh our God is holy.
A psalm of thanksgiving.
v 1
Shout joyfully to Yahweh, all the earth.
v 2
Serve Yahweh with gladness;
come before his presence with joyful singing.
v 3
Know that Yahweh is God;
he made us, and we are his.
We are his people and the sheep of his pasture.
v 4
Enter into his gates with thanksgiving
and into his courts with praise.
Give thanks to him and bless his name.
v 5
For Yahweh is good; his covenant faithfulness endures forever
and his truthfulness through all generations.
A psalm of David.
v 1
I will sing of covenant faithfulness and justice;
to you, Yahweh, I will sing praises.
v 2
I will walk in the way of integrity.
Oh, when will you come to me?
I will walk with integrity within my house.
v 3
I will not put wrongdoing before my eyes;
I hate worthless evil;
it will not cling to me.
v 4
Perverse people will leave me;
I am not loyal to evil.
v 5
I will destroy whoever secretly slanders his neighbor.
I will not tolerate anyone who has a proud demeanor and an arrogant attitude.
v 6
I will look to the faithful of the land to sit at my side.
Those who walk in the way of integrity may serve me.
v 7
Deceitful people will not remain within my house;
liars will not be welcome before my eyes.
v 8
Morning by morning I will destroy all the wicked from the land;
I will remove all evildoers from the city of Yahweh.
A prayer of the afflicted when he is faint and pours out his lament before Yahweh.
v 1
Hear my prayer, Yahweh;
hear my cry to you.
v 2
Do not hide your face from me in my time of trouble.
Listen to me.
When I call out to you, answer me quickly.
v 3
For my days pass away like smoke,
and my bones burn like fire.
v 4
My heart is crushed, and I am like grass that has withered.
I forget to eat any food.
v 5
With my continual groaning,
I have become very thin.
v 6
I am like a pelican of the wilderness;
I have become like an owl in the ruins.
v 7
I lie awake like a solitary bird,
alone on the housetop.
v 8
My enemies taunt me all day long;
those who mock me use my name in curses.
v 9
I eat ashes like bread
and mix my drink with tears.
Because of your raging anger,
you have lifted me up to throw me down.
My days are like a shadow that fades,
and I have withered like grass.
But you, Yahweh, live forever,
and your fame is for all generations.
You will rise up and have mercy on Zion.
Now is the time to have mercy upon her;
the appointed time has come.
For your servants hold her stones dear
and feel compassion for the dust of her ruins.
The nations will respect your name, Yahweh,
and all the kings of the earth will honor your glory.
Yahweh will rebuild Zion
and will appear in his glory.
At that time, he will respond to the prayer of the destitute;
he will not reject their prayer.
This will be written for future generations,
and a people not yet born will praise Yahweh.
For he has looked down from the holy heights;
from heaven Yahweh has viewed the earth,
to hear the groaning of the prisoners,
to release those who were condemned to death.
Then men will proclaim the name of Yahweh in Zion
and his praise in Jerusalem
when the peoples and kingdoms gather together
to serve Yahweh.
He has taken away my strength in the middle of life.
He has shortened my days.
I said, “My God, do not take me away in the middle of life;
you are here throughout all generations.
In ancient times you set the earth in place;
the heavens are the work of your hands.
They will perish, but you will remain;
they will all grow old like a garment;
like clothing, you will remove them, and they will disappear.
But you are the same,
and your years will have no end.
The children of your servants will live on,
and their descendants will live in your presence.”
A psalm of David.
v 1
I give praise to Yahweh with all my life,
and with all that is within me, I give praise to his holy name.
v 2
I give praise to Yahweh with all my life,
and I remember all of his good deeds.
v 3
He forgives all your sins;
he heals all your diseases.
v 4
He redeems your life from destruction;
he crowns you with covenant faithfulness and acts of tender mercy.
v 5
He satisfies your life with good things
so that your youth is renewed like the eagle.
v 6
Yahweh does what is fair
and does acts of justice for all who are oppressed.
v 7
He made known his ways to Moses,
his deeds to the descendants of Israel.
v 8
Yahweh is merciful and gracious;
he is patient; he has great covenant loyalty.
v 9
He will not always discipline;
he is not always angry.
He does not deal with us as our sins deserve
or repay us for what our sins demand.
For as the skies are high above the earth,
so great is his covenant faithfulness toward those who honor him.
As far as the east is from the west,
this is how far he has removed the guilt of our sins from us.
As a father has compassion on his children,
so Yahweh has compassion on those who honor him.
For he knows how we are formed;
he knows that we are dust.
As for man, his days are like grass;
he flourishes like a flower in a field.
The wind blows over it, and it disappears,
and no one can even tell where it once grew.
But the covenant faithfulness of Yahweh is from everlasting to everlasting on those who honor him.
His righteousness extends to their descendants.
They keep his covenant
and remember to obey his instructions.
Yahweh has established his throne in the heavens,
and his kingdom rules over everyone.
Give praise to Yahweh, you his angels,
you mighty ones who are strong and do his word,
and obey the sound of his word.
Give praise to Yahweh, all his hosts,
you are his servants who carry out his will.
Give praise to Yahweh, all his creatures,
in all the places where he reigns.
I will give praise to Yahweh with all my life.
v 1
I give praise to Yahweh with all my life,
Yahweh my God, you are very magnificent;
